text.tspan: I am a 3ʳᵈ year PhD student in computer science,
working within the Partout team of the LIX laboratory
under the supervision of Benjamin Werner.
My work lies at the intersection between mathematical
logic and human-computer interaction, with applications
to interactive theorem proving. More precisely, I try to
theories that are better suited to direct manipulation
by humans, but still understandable by computers.
Ultimately, my hope is that computing technologies
will enable a new era of digitized mathematics, where
mathematical knowledge can be efficiently shared,
reused and experimented upon by any curious mind.
In light of the Curry-Howard correspondance, I believe
this vision equally applies to the realm of programs.
If you want to discuss any of these subjects, please
feel free to send me a message at

, because of the way I like
to draw the graphs as nested flowers.
I am a member of the Transcendentalist
Circle, a working group on the foundations
of logic and computation in light of J.-Y.

Since the day I discovered computers, I have been fascinated by their ability to represent and give life to human
intentions. I quickly got into programming to unlock their full creative potential, but always felt a discrepancy
between the immediacy and intuitiveness of graphical interfaces, and the expressivity and rigidity of programming
Then I discovered formal logic, a field that claims to capture
computation. This really hit home, as the experience of
meaningfulness of my own thoughts. How could I ever be sure the programs I wrote would always behave in the way
I intended them to? Formal logic provided a language to clarify my intent, and guarantee that programs respect it.
Now although I love analysing things under the logico-computational microscope, I feel like it focuses too much on
, and the way they can be classified and checked for validity. It assumes I already know what I
want, and how to express it symbolically. What I seek for is a
enabling a true collaboration with the
computer, one where I can freely visualize, manipulate, transform and discover new ideas under its guidance,
instead of squeezing my thoughts in its pre-existing categories. Meaning should emerge from my interaction with the
computer and its users, not from my head.
Today I believe that logic can offer principled ways of designing and evolving such formats. This is because logicians
have developed conceptual tools to specify meaning
, before knowing its precise embodiment. But to make
this reality possible, we need to rethink the architecture of the logical edifice, so that we can articulate formats in a
less rigid, more interoperable way. We need to open logic to the world, rather than try to fit the world into logics.
I will give a talk at CoqPL 2023 in Boston on
proof assistants • constructive logics • ⁠ proof theory • ⁠ deep inference • ⁠ existential graphs • ⁠ programming
language theory • ⁠ Curry-Howard correspondance • ⁠ end-user proving⁠ • ⁠ gestural interfaces
